abstracts.cdata!:
The project's overall rating is
            satisfactory with project sustainability adjudged as likely.
            World Bank performance received a rating of
            satisfactory-to-highly satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory overall. Several lessons
            emerge: The medium- and long-term sustainability of a
            country's reform program depends on having provincial
            governments that do not generate excessive fiscal deficits
            and are efficient providers of services. Multi-sectoral
            loans can be effective tools in doing the groundwork for
            reform. By being willing to take a moderate risk in
            approving the project under still unstable macroeconomic
            conditions, the Bank was able to help Argentina capitalize
            on the unique window of opportunity that opened after the
            Convertibility Law. Enhanced responsibilities for
            sub-national governments contribute to strong ownership of
            the project as well as "hands-on" capacity
            building. Simplify as much as possible all review,
            procurement, and disbursement procedures. Do not expect
            multi-sectoral projects to disburse quickly and easily at
            first. Develop a portfolio of alternative sources of
            financing for provincial investment to increase reform
            leverage. Adequate supervision resources should be made
            available. Having the provincial finance ministers as
            counterparts served to keep the focus on reform-oriented
            sub-projects. To improve quality control of the portfolio in
            multi-sectoral operations, the subcontracting of supervision
            activities should be considered.
